From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
"Presidents of the United States" redirects here. For other uses, see
President of the United States (disambiguation) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States_(disambiguation))
.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:White_House_Washington.JPG)
The
White House (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House)
, official residence of the president of the United States
The
president of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States)
is the
head of state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_state)
and
head of government (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_government)
of the
United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States)
,
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTERossiter196286-1)
indirectly elected (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indirectly_elected)
to a four-year
term (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_of_office)
via the
Electoral College (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College)
.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShugart2004633–636-2)
Under the
U.S. Constitution (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Constitution)
, the officeholder leads the
executive branch (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government))
of the
federal government (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States)
and is the
commander-in-chief (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commander-in-chief)
of the
United States Armed Forces (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces)
.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpstein2005318-3)
The first president,
George Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Washington)
, won a unanimous vote of the Electoral College.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatuz2001xxii-4)
The incumbent president is
Donald Trump (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)
, who
assumed office on January 20, 2025 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_inauguration_of_Donald_Trump)
.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHajela2024-5)
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreile2024-6)
Since the office was established in 1789, 45 men have served in 47 presidencies. The discrepancy is due to the nonconsecutive terms of
Grover Cleveland (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grover_Cleveland)
, counted as the 22nd and 24th president, and Trump, counted as the 45th and 47th president.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAP2024-7)
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchallerWilliams2003192-8)
The presidency of
William Henry Harrison (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison)
, who died 31 days after taking office in 1841, was the shortest in American history.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcHughMackowiak2014990–995-9)
Franklin D. Roosevelt (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt)
served the longest, over twelve years, before dying early in his fourth term in 1945. He is the only U.S. president to have served more than two terms.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkau1974246–275-10)
Since the ratification of the
Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution)
in 1951, no person may be elected president more than twice, and no one who has served more than two years of a term to which someone else was elected may be elected more than once.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeabodyGant1999565-11)
Four presidents died in office of natural causes (William Henry Harrison,
Zachary Taylor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zachary_Taylor)
,
Warren G. Harding (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_G._Harding)
, and Franklin D. Roosevelt), four were
assassinated (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_assassination_attempts_and_plots)
(
Abraham Lincoln (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln)
,
James A. Garfield (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_A._Garfield)
,
William McKinley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_McKinley)
, and
John F. Kennedy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy)
), and one resigned (
Richard Nixon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Nixon)
, facing
impeachment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_process_against_Richard_Nixon)
and removal from office).
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbbott2005627–644-12)
John Tyler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Tyler)
was the first
vice president (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States)
to assume the presidency during a presidential term, setting the precedent that a vice president who does so becomes the fully functioning president with a new, distinct administration.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDinnerstein1962447–451-13)
Throughout most of its history,
American politics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_politics)
has been dominated by
political parties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_parties_in_the_United_States)
. The Constitution is silent on the issue of political parties, and at the time it came into force in 1789, no organized parties existed. Soon after the
1st Congress (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1st_United_States_Congress)
convened,
political factions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_faction)
began rallying around dominant
Washington administration (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_George_Washington)
officials, such as
Alexander Hamilton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton)
and
Thomas Jefferson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson)
.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Guide_to_U.S._Elections''2010197Nardulli1992179-14)
Concerned about the capacity of political parties to destroy the fragile unity holding the nation together, Washington remained
unaffiliated (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_politician)
with any political faction or party throughout his eight-year presidency. He was, and remains, the only U.S. president who never affiliated with a political party.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELOC_(2)Jamison2014-15)

Notes
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-16)
Presidents are numbered according to uninterrupted periods served by the same person. For example, George Washington served two consecutive terms and is counted as the first president, instead of the first and second, but Grover Cleveland and Donald Trump are counted twice because their two terms were not consecutive. A vice president who temporarily becomes
acting president (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acting_President_of_the_United_States)
under the
Twenty-fifth Amendment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution)
to the Constitution is not counted, because the president remains in office during such a period.
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-18)
Reflects the president's political party at the start of their presidency. Changes during their time in office are noted. Also reflects the vice president's political party unless otherwise noted beside the individual's name.
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-23)
Political parties had not been anticipated when the Constitution was drafted, nor did they exist at the time of the first presidential election in 1788–89. When they did develop, during Washington's first term, Adams joined the faction that became the
Federalist Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalist_Party)
. The elections of 1792 were the first ones in the United States that were contested on anything resembling a partisan basis.
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Guide_to_U.S._Elections''2010197,_272Nardulli1992179-22)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-26)
The 1796 presidential election was the first contested American presidential election and the only one in which a president and vice president were elected from opposing political parties. Federalist John Adams was elected president, and Jefferson of the Democratic-Republicans was elected vice president.
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Guide_to_U.S._Elections''2010274-25)

Died in office
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeale200422-29)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-JQAdams_34-0)
Early during John Quincy Adams' term, the
Democratic-Republican Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party)
dissolved; his allies in Congress and at the state level were referred to as "Adams' Men" during the Adams presidency. When
Andrew Jackson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Jackson)
became president in 1829, this group became the "Anti-Jackson"
opposition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opposition_(politics))
, and organized themselves as the
National Republican Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Republican_Party)
.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Guide_to_U.S._Elections''2010228Goldman1951159-33)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-36)
John Calhoun, formerly a Democratic-Republican, founded the
Nullifier Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nullifier_Party)
in 1828 to oppose the
Tariff of 1828 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff_of_Abominations)
and advance the cause of
states' rights (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States%27_rights)
, but was brought on as Andrew Jackson's running mate in the 1828 presidential election in an effort to broaden the democratic coalition led by Jackson.
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Guide_to_U.S._Elections''2010892Houpt201026,_280-35)
^

John Tyler succeeded to the presidency upon the death of William Henry Harrison.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbbott201323-42)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-JTyler_45-0)
John Tyler was elected vice president on the Whig Party ticket in 1840. His policy priorities as president soon proved to be opposed to most of the Whig agenda, and he was expelled from the party five months after assuming office.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTECash201834–36-44)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-50)
Millard Fillmore succeeded to the presidency upon the death of Zachary Taylor.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbbott2005639-49)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-ALincoln_55-0)
When he ran for reelection in 1864, Republican Abraham Lincoln formed a bipartisan
electoral alliance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electoral_alliance)
with
War Democrats (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_Democrat)
by selecting Democrat Andrew Johnson as his running mate, and running on the
National Union Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Union_Party_(United_States))
ticket.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcSeveney1986139-54)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-57)
Andrew Johnson succeeded to the presidency upon the death of Abraham Lincoln.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrefousse2000-56)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-AJohnson_58-0)
While president, Andrew Johnson tried and failed to build a coalition of loyalists under the National Union banner. Near the end of his presidency, Johnson began reassociating with the Democratic Party.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrefousse2000-56)
^ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#cite_ref-64)
Chester A. Arthur succeeded to the presidency upon the death of James A. Garfield.

Theodore Roosevelt succeeded to the presidency upon the death of William McKinley.

Calvin Coolidge succeeded to the presidency upon the death of Warren G. Harding.

Harry S. Truman succeeded to the presidency upon the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Gerald Ford succeeded to the presidency upon the resignation of Richard Nixon. Even though Ford served out the remainder of Nixon's second term, he was never elected to the presidency or vice presidency.

Michael Everett Capuano
(
/ˌkæpjuˈɑːnoʊ/ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English)
KAP-ew-AH-noh (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key)
; born January 9, 1952) is an American politician and attorney  who served as a
U.S. Representative (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives)
of
Massachusetts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts)
from 1999 to 2019. A
Democrat (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States))
, his district included the northern three-fourths of
Boston (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston)
, as well as parts of
Cambridge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts)
, his hometown of
Somerville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somerville,_Massachusetts)
, and other communities immediately north and south of Boston. Prior to being elected to
Congress (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress)
, he served as an
Alderman (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alderman)
and
Mayor of Somerville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Somerville,_Massachusetts)
.
Capuano was born and raised in Somerville. After graduating from
Dartmouth College (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_College)
and
Boston College Law School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_College_Law_School)
, he worked as an attorney and Somerville alderman. After losing two mayoral elections in 1979 and 1981, he worked as legal counsel for the
Massachusetts General Court (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court)
. In 1989 Capuano ran for mayor a third time and won, serving from 1990 to 1999.
In 1998 Capuano won a crowded Democratic primary to replace
Joseph Kennedy II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kennedy_II)
in Congress and was re-elected nine times. He represented the state's
8th district (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts%27s_8th_congressional_district)
until it was redrawn in 2013 into the
7th district (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts%27s_7th_congressional_district)
. In Congress he was a staunch
liberal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States)
and member of the
Congressional Progressive Caucus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Progressive_Caucus)
.
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-1)
He ran in the
2010 special election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Massachusetts,_2010)
to fill the seat in the
United States Senate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate)
made vacant by the death of
Ted Kennedy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Kennedy)
, his Congressional predecessor's uncle, but lost the primary to
Martha Coakley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Coakley)
, who in turn lost the general election to Republican
Scott Brown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Brown_(politician))
. In 2018, he was defeated by
Ayanna Pressley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayanna_Pressley)
in a House Democratic primary.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-2)
In March 2019, Capuano joined the law firm
Foley & Lardner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foley_%26_Lardner)
, to serve as public affairs director.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-3)
The same month, he also joined
Boston University (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_University)
to teach at the university's
Initiative on Cities (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initiative_on_Cities)
and help organize the program.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-4)
Early life and education
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=1)
]
Capuano was born January 9, 1952, in the
Spring Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_Hill,_Somerville,_Massachusetts)
neighborhood of
Somerville, Massachusetts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somerville,_Massachusetts)
, the son of Rita Marie (née Garvey) and Andrew Capuano. His father left to serve in
World War II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II)
shortly after his marriage, and after returning ran for the Somerville Board of Aldermen, and became the first
Italian American (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Americans)
elected to the board. His mother was of Irish descent.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-rita-2010-5)
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-post-bio-6)
Capuano graduated from
Somerville High School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somerville_High_School_(Massachusetts))
in 1969, and later attended
Dartmouth College (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_College)
, where he graduated with a
Bachelor of Arts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts)
in 1973. Capuano later went on to earn his
Juris Doctor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juris_Doctor)
in 1977 from
Boston College Law School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_College_Law_School)
, specializing in tax law.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-directory-2009-7)
Early political career
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=2)
]
In 1976, Capuano was elected to the Somerville Board of Aldermen representing Ward 5, once served in by his father.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-directory-2009-7)
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-8)
Capuano served one term, stepping down in 1979 to run for
Mayor of Somerville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Somerville,_Massachusetts)
.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-flint-1998-9)
In the 1979 mayoral election he faced Eugene Brune, Paul Haley, and incumbent, Thomas August. He lost the nomination to Brune, who went on to defeat August.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-10)
Capuano ran again in 1981 to challenge Brune, placing second in a three-person runoff election.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-11)
Capuano promoted his opposition to the state ballot question
Proposition 2½ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proposition_2%C2%BD)
and criticized Brune for expanding the mayoral staff in the face of tight city budgets, while Brune touted his prevention of service cuts after the proposition passed.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-12)
Capuano lost in the general election with 40% of the vote.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-13)
From 1978 to 1984 Capuano served as chief legal counsel for the
Massachusetts General Court (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court)
's Joint Committee on Taxation.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-bioguide-14)
Capuano left the committee in 1984 to join the
Beacon Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beacon_Hill,_Boston)
law firm and lobbying group Joyce & Joyce.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-flint-1998-9)
In 1985 he returned to the Somerville Board of Aldermen as an at-large member.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-bioguide-14)
Mayor of Somerville
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=3)
]
In 1989 Capuano ran for mayor a third time and won.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-directory-2009-7)
Capuano served as mayor from 1990 to 1999, where he earned a reputation as a hands-on administrator.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-goldberg-1998-15)
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-ferdinand-1998-16)
One of his priorities was to lower the city's population density, which at the time was the highest of any
New England (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England)
municipality, by using state grants to demolish several buildings and replace them with playgrounds and parking spaces.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-kenney-1994-17)
As mayor, Capuano oversaw the reduction of school class sizes to a maximum of 19 students.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-goldberg-1998-15)
U.S. House of Representatives
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=4)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Capuano_and_Clooney.jpg)
Capuano with actor
George Clooney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Clooney)
in
Darfur (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darfur)
Elections
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=5)
]
In 1998,
Joseph Kennedy II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kennedy_II)
announced his retirement after six terms in what was then the 8th District. Capuano entered a crowded 10-way Democratic primary—the real contest in this heavily Democratic district, which was once represented by
John F. Kennedy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy)
and
Tip O'Neill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tip_O%27Neill)
. The early front-runner was former
Boston Mayor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Boston)
and
US Vatican Ambassador (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_Holy_See)
Raymond Flynn (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Flynn)
. However, Capuano won the primary with 23%, largely due to large turnout in Somerville, all but assuring him of election in November.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-goldberg-1998-15)
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-ferdinand-1998-16)
He easily won the general election in November, taking 81 percent of the vote. He was reelected nine times, never dropping below 80% of the vote in what has long been the most Democratic district in New England. Since his initial run for the seat, Capuano was unopposed in all but two reelection bids; he faced a minor-party candidate in 2006 and an independent in 2012. He faced a
Republican (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States))
only once, during his initial run in 1998.
2018 election
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=6)
]
See also:
2018 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts § District 7 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Massachusetts#District_7)
Capuano was defeated by Boston City Councilor
Ayanna Pressley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayanna_Pressley)
in the September 4, 2018, primary election, receiving 41.3% of the vote versus Pressley's 58.5%.
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-18)
The Boston Globe (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Boston_Globe)
reported that Capuano did not get the endorsement of either U.S. Senator from Massachusetts,
Elizabeth Warren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Warren)
and
Edward J. Markey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_J._Markey)
, nor was he endorsed by Representatives
Seth Moulton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seth_Moulton)
and
Niki Tsongas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niki_Tsongas)
. Capuano did receive the support of the majority of the Massachusetts federal delegation, including Representatives
William Keating (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Keating_(politician))
,
Katherine Clark (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Clark)
,
James McGovern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_McGovern_(American_politician))
,
Joseph Kennedy III (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kennedy_III)
,
Stephen Lynch (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_F._Lynch)
, and
Richard Neal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Neal)
.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-19)
Capuano was endorsed by Congressman
John Lewis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Lewis)
(D-GA), on March 7, 2018; Lewis described Capuano as "a champion and fierce advocate for those who have often been forgotten or left behind" and "a leader alongside those of us opposing the unfair and immoral policies of the Trump Administration."
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-20)
In its editorial endorsement of Pressley, the
Boston Globe
noted that the state Legislature had drawn the 7th district to favor minority candidates.
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-21)
No Republican even filed, all but assuring Pressley of being the district's next congresswoman.
Tenure
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=7)
]
Committee assignments
115th Congress (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/115th_United_States_Congress)
(2017–19)
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-22)
Financial Services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Financial_Services)
Financial Institutions and Consumer Credit (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Financial_Services_Subcommittee_on_Financial_Institutions_and_Consumer_Credit)
Housing and Insurance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Financial_Services_Subcommittee_on_Housing_and_Insurance)
Oversight and Investigations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Financial_Services_Subcommittee_on_Oversight_and_Investigations)
Transportation and Infrastructure (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Transportation_and_Infrastructure)
Aviation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Transportation_Subcommittee_on_Aviation)
Highways and Transit (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Transportation_Subcommittee_on_Highways_and_Transit)
Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Transportation_Subcommittee_on_Railroads,_Pipelines,_and_Hazardous_Materials)
(ranking member)
During his tenure, Capuano helped found five congressional caucuses, on: Community Health Centers;
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-23)
Empowerment Zones and Enterprise Communities;
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-24)
Sudan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudan)
;
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-25)
and
Korea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korea)
;
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-26)
as well as one for former
Mayors (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayoralty_in_the_United_States)
.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-27)
Capuano voted against the
War in Iraq (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_Resolution)
and supported immediate withdrawal of troops. In 2005 Capuano visited Iraq and met with military leaders to assess the future of the region.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-28)
Capuano is considered to be one of the biggest supporters in Congress for increasing international aid funding,
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-29)
and has advocated bringing attention to the
crisis in Sudan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Darfur)
and helped secure funding aimed at assisting developing African nations.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-Capuano_Who_Runs_Gov-30)
Capuano is
pro-choice (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro-choice)
and supports open access to abortions. In 2012 a fundraiser hosted by
Pope John XXIII High School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII_High_School_(Everett,_Massachusetts))
where Capuano and fellow Massachusetts Congressman
Ed Markey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Markey)
were to receive awards was cancelled due to their "positions [being] inconsistent with
church doctrine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church)
;" both were humble in response to the news.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-31)
During the
2010 Senate Democratic primary (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Massachusetts,_2010)
Capuano criticized his opponent
Martha Coakley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Coakley)
, claiming she wouldn't have voted for the
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act)
with
Stupak–Pitts Amendment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stupak%E2%80%93Pitts_Amendment)
which would have barred federal funding of abortions; which Capuano said he only did to "keep the health care debate alive."
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-32)
Capuano's comments were characterized by
WBUR (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBUR)
political analyst as "an empty charge against her since he has the same position as she does."
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-33)
After the
2006 election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_general_elections,_2006)
that created a Democratic majority in the House, he was appointed Chairman of the Speaker's Task Force on Ethics Enforcement by
Nancy Pelosi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi)
, with whom he has a close relationship. After serving as the Chairman of the Task Force on Ethics Enforcement, in 2008 Capuano introduced
H.R. 895 (https://www.congress.gov/bill/110th-congress/house-bill/895)
which established the
Office of Congressional Ethics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_Congressional_Ethics)
.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-34)
Capuano has had a long-running relationship with former Congressman
Anthony Weiner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Weiner)
, whom he shared a
Washington, D.C. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.)
apartment with for 12 years. Following Weiner's
sexting scandal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Weiner_sexting_scandal)
Capuano did not call on him to resign, saying: "I am not the guy who likes to judge other people. I figure that is between them and the people who are appropriately named to do that – and that is the Ethics Committee."
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-35)
Capuano is a strong supporter of labor rights and unions; in February 2011 during a rally at
Beacon Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beacon_Hill,_Boston)
in Boston, in support of the
2011 Wisconsin budget protests (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wisconsin_budget_protests)
, Capuano told the crowd, "I'm proud to be here with people who understand that it's more than just sending an email to get you going. Every once and awhile you need to get out on the streets and get a little bloody when necessary". Following criticism, especially when such a statement was made just days after the
attempted assassination (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Tucson_shooting)
of
Gabby Giffords (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabby_Giffords)
, Capuano expressed regret for his "choice of words."
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-36)
After the
2008 financial crisis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_financial_crisis)
and subsequent
bank bailouts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troubled_Asset_Relief_Program)
, at a
House Financial Services Committee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Financial_Services)
hearing, Capuano berated the bank
CEOs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CEO)
for their practices, saying at one point: "You come to us today on your bicycles after buying Girl Scout cookies and helping out
Mother Teresa (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_Teresa)
and telling us, 'We're sorry, we didn't mean it, we won't do it again, trust us.' Well, I have some people in my constituency that actually robbed some of your banks and they say the same thing."
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-37)
Capuano's speech was included in the 2010
documentary film (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Documentary_film)
Inside Job (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inside_Job_(2010_film))
, described by
director (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_director)
Charles H. Ferguson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_H._Ferguson)
as being about "the systemic corruption of the United States by the
financial services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_services)
industry and the consequences of that systemic corruption."
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-38)
A self-described "
fiscal conservative (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiscal_conservatism)
" who opposed the Bush-era tax cuts that provided tax reductions for the wealthy because they "created a deficit for no good reason,"
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-39)
in 2013 Capuano joined
Senator (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate)
Elizabeth Warren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Warren)
and
Boston Mayor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Boston)
Thomas Menino (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Menino)
in a rally against the then-upcoming
sequester (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budget_sequestration_in_2013)
, with Capuano calling it "stupid."
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-40)
In 2012 Capuano along with fellow Massachusetts Congressman
Barney Frank (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barney_Frank)
introduced legislation to combine the
Securities and Exchange Commission (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission)
and
Commodity Futures Trading Commission (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodity_Futures_Trading_Commission)
into the "Securities and Derivatives Commission."
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-41)
Capuano was a member of the
Congressional Arts Caucus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Arts_Caucus)
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-42)
and the
U.S.-Japan Caucus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S.-Japan_Caucus)
.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-43)
Campaigns for higher office
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=8)
]
1994 Secretary nomination
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=9)
]
Capuano ran for
Massachusetts Secretary of the Commonwealth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Secretary_of_the_Commonwealth)
in the
1994 election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_general_election,_1994#Secretary_of_the_Commonwealth)
, running against former
State Representatives (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_House_of_Representatives)
Augusto Grace (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augusto_Grace)
and
William F. Galvin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_F._Galvin)
for the Democratic nomination. During the race he framed himself as an advocate for the poor and urban communities, and criticized aid formulas which he argued left less-wealthy municipalities with less per-capita revenue. To appear on the Democratic primary required the support of at least 15% of delegates in the state party convention. In what the
Boston Globe (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Globe)
deemed "an embarrassing defeat," he failed to obtain the necessary delegate votes to be nominated to participate in the primary election,  with only 13%. When asked why he undertook the difficult race to begin with, he responded, "Because I wasn't ready to run for
Governor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_Massachusetts)
."
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-kenney-1994-17)
2010 Senate campaign
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=10)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wikinews-logo.svg)
Wikinews has related news:
Brown, Coakley win Massachusetts Senate seat primaries amid low voter turnout (https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Brown,_Coakley_win_Massachusetts_Senate_seat_primaries_amid_low_voter_turnout)
Main article:
2010 United States Senate special election in Massachusetts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Massachusetts)
After the death of incumbent Senator
Ted Kennedy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Kennedy)
, a special election to succeed him was scheduled. On September 8, 2009, Capuano collected nomination papers to run for the seat
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-herald-2009-09-08-44)
and on September 18, he announced his candidacy.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-45)
Capuano ran as a "Washington insider," comparing himself to Kennedy saying: "was [Kennedy] not the ultimate insider ... I think that's probably one of the best things that we share."
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-46)
In his campaign Capuano received several high-profile endorsements, including House Speaker Pelosi and former Massachusetts Governor and
1988 Democratic presidential nominee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_United_States_presidential_election)
,
Michael Dukakis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Dukakis)
.
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-47)
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-48)
Consistently polling below incumbent
Massachusetts Attorney General (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Attorney_General)
,
Martha Coakley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Coakley)
, on December 8, 2009, Capuano lost the Democratic primary to Coakley, winning only 28% of the vote to Coakley's 47%, amongst a field of four candidates.
2014 gubernatorial election
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=11)
]
Further information:
2014 Massachusetts gubernatorial election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Massachusetts_gubernatorial_election)
Capuano considered running for
Governor of Massachusetts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_Massachusetts)
in
2014 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_gubernatorial_election,_2014)
.
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-49)
On January 21, 2013, former mayor of
Springfield, Massachusetts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Massachusetts)
, and member of the
Massachusetts Governor's Council (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Governor%27s_Council)
Michael Albano (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Albano)
endorsed Capuano to run, posting on his
Facebook (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook)
page: "while the Congressman has not made a decision to compete for the [Democratic] nomination [for Governor] at this time, it is not too early to make the case and encourage his candidacy."
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-50)
When asked in February 2013 whether he might run for governor, Capuano responded: "Part of me thinks that some of the more interesting, more important fights over the next several years might be conducted at statehouses around the country and not necessarily on
Capitol Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitol_Hill)
."
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-51)
In a statement in September 2013, Capuano announced he would not run for governor, and would instead focus on running for re-election to Congress.
[52] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-52)
Personal life
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mike_Capuano&action=edit&section=12)
]
Capuano was named after his two grandfathers,
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-post-bio-6)
and has seven siblings, one of whom died in infancy, and another who died of
polio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polio)
at the age of 5.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-rita-2010-5)
Capuano married Barbara Teebagy in 1974, and together they have two sons: Michael and Joseph.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-directory-2009-7)
He is the uncle of actors
Chris Evans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Evans_(actor))
of the
Captain America (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain_America:_The_First_Avenger)
film series, and
Scott Evans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Evans_(actor))
of the soap opera
One Life to Live (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Life_to_Live)
through his sister Lisa.
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-53)
In 2003, the City of Somerville dedicated a new school in Capuano's honor; the Michael E. Capuano Early Childhood Center officially opened in September that year.
[54] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-54)
Capuano is a Roman Catholic.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-:0-55)
Before
Pope Francis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_Francis)
became pope and shifted the tone of the Church, Capuano used to fear that his mother would be embarrassed if he was ever denied communion because of his support for gay marriage and abortion rights.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Capuano#cite_note-:0-55)

https://www.biography.com/actor/chris-ev:
Title: Chris Evans

URL Source: https://www.biography.com/actor/chris-evans

Published Time: 2018-04-24T21:50:35Z

Markdown Content:
> 1981-present

Who Is Chris Evans?
-------------------

Born and raised in the Boston area, Chris Evans landed his first major film role in the spoof _Not Another Teen Movie_. He played the Human Torch in two _Fantastic Four_ flicks, but it was his turn as another superhero that propelled him to fame in the enormously successful _Captain America_ and _The Avenger_ s blockbusters. Evans also earned acclaim for his performance in the dystopian _Snowpiercer_ and made a well-received Broadway debut in 2018.

Quick Facts
-----------

FULL NAME: Christopher Robert Evans

BORN: June 13, 1981

BIRTHPLACE: Boston, Massachusetts

SPOUSE: Alba Baptista (m. 2023)

ASTROLOGICAL SIGN: Gemini

Early Life
----------

Christopher Robert Evans was born on June 13, 1981, in Boston, Massachusetts, and raised in the nearby town of Sudbury. While his dad, Robert, provided financial stability as a dentist, Evans and his three siblings were drawn to the performing arts world of their mother, Lisa, a dancer turned youth theater director. As Evans recalled, “We were like the von Trapps [from _The Sound of Music_], all singing and dancing.”

A natural athlete, Evans wrestled and played lacrosse at Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School, when not invested in his school or community theater. He spent the summer before his senior year of high school interning for a casting company in New York City, making valuable contacts and honing his skills at the Lee Strasberg Institute. Eager to return, the aspiring actor sped through his senior year to graduate a half semester ahead of his classmates.

Movies and TV Shows
-------------------

Sent to Los Angeles by his agent in the late 1990s to audition for a show called _Get Real_ (where he met [Anne Hathaway](https://www.biography.com/actors/anne-hathaway)), Evans instead wound up with a supporting role on _Opposite Sex,_ alongside Milo Ventimiglia, as one of the few boys to attend a former all-girls academy. The teen comedy-drama lasted for only eight episodes in the summer of 2000, but still provided vital exposure for its young stars. Evans went on to make appearances in _The Fugitive_, _Skin_ and the popular _Boston Public_.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Evans’ first major film role came in _Not Another Teen Movie_ (2001), a spoof of high school dramas like _She’s All That_ (1999) and earlier predecessors. As football star Jake Wyler, he follows the formulaic procedure of accepting a bet to date the nerdy, glasses-wearing girl, delivering a silly highlight by squirting on the whipped cream bikini made famous by Ali Larter in _Varsity Blues_ (1999).

He followed with another high school comedy, _The Perfect Score_ (2004), as part of a group of students who steal the answers to an SAT exam, and then the action-thriller _Cellular_ (2004), where he showed his future leading man chops by helping to rescue Kim Basinger from her captors.

_Fantastic Four_, _Scott Pilgrim_, and Other Comic Adaptations
--------------------------------------------------------------

Prior to his star-making turn in _Captain America_, Evans went the superhero route for _Fantastic Four_ (2005), as Johnny Storm/Human Torch. The film was a commercial success, but a downturn at the box office for _Rise of the Silver Surfer_ (2007), along with another round of largely negative reviews, led to the cancellation of a third installment.

Returning to comic-sourced material, Evans provided voice work for the animated _TMNT_ (2007), as the boyfriend of the Ninja Turtles’ colleague, April O’Neil. In 2008, with his successful film career well under way, Evans provided voice work for Adult Swim’s stop-motion series _Robot Chicken_.

He later co-starred in the action comedy _The Losers_ (2010), which drew mixed reviews despite a strong cast, and landed a supporting role in the entertaining _Scott Pilgrim vs. the World_ (2010), as an over-the-top version of the Hollywood action hero he had become.

Meanwhile, the actor took advantage of the all-American good looks and charm that made him a natural for romantic comedies. He played the “Harvard Hottie” of past and future co-star [Scarlett Johannson](https://www.biography.com/actors/scarlett-johansson) in _The Nanny Diaries_ (2007), before becoming the ideal match for Anna Faris in _What’s Your Number?_ (2011).

Marvel Cinematic Universe: _Captain America_ and _The Avengers_
---------------------------------------------------------------

In July 2011, Evans joined the burgeoning Marvel Cinematic Universe empire with _Captain America: The First Avenger_. As Steve Rogers, the scrawny but dutiful serviceman who undergoes a massive physical transformation to become the titular super soldier, Evans capably displayed the earnestness central to his character, along with the eye-popping physique and fighting skills requisite for a modern action star.

_The First Avenger_ was just the start of the MCU run for Evans, who joined [Robert Downey Jr.](https://www.biography.com/actors/robert-downey-jr)’s Iron Man, [Chris Hemsworth](https://www.biography.com/actors/chris-hemsworth)’s Thor and other big-name actors, both in and out of costume, for the superhero blockbuster _The Avengers_ (2012). Evans went on to headline the sequels of his own _Captain America_ franchise with _The_ _Winter Soldier_ (2014) and _Civil War_ (2016), while also leading the charge for _The Avengers: Age of Ultron_ (2015) and surfacing in other Marvel features, like _Ant-Man_ (2015) and _Spider-Man: Homecoming_ (2017).

Initially reluctant to wield the Captain’s shield due to the extended commitment, Evans was ready to move on by the time his contract drew to a close, with _Avengers: Infinity War_ (2018) and _Avengers: Endgame_ (2019) showcasing his final performances as America's super solider.

Drama and Sci-Fi: _London_ to _Snowpiercer_
-------------------------------------------

Coming off his early teen films, Evans showed he could handle weightier fare with _London_ (2005), as a junkie struggling to get over his ex-girlfriend. He later took on [Tennessee Williams](https://www.biography.com/authors-writers/tennessee-williams) in _The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond_ (2008), with [Bryce Dallas Howard](https://www.biography.com/actors/bryce-dallas-howard), and portrayed a real-life lawyer and drug addict who goes after the pharmaceutical industry in _Puncture_ (2010).

On the sci-fi front, Evans co-starred in Danny Boyle’s little-seen but critically acclaimed _Sunshine_ (2007), as an engineer on a space mission to jumpstart the dying sun. His effort was praised by its director, who called Evans “a bit of a Mary Poppins—he can pull anything out of the bag.” He then played a telekinetic in _Push_ (2009), though his performance was drowned out by a confusing plot.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Despite his Marvel commitments requiring much of his energy, Evans found the time for other screen projects to his liking. _Iceman_ (2012) gave him the chance to overturn his squeaky-clean superhero image as a contract killer who assists Michael Shannon’s sadistic hitman. _Snowpiercer_ (2013) placed him back in leading man territory, albeit as an antihero in a dystopian future.

_Before We Go_ and _The Gifted_
-------------------------------

The actor made his directing debut with _Before We Go_, a tepidly received romantic comedy that premiered at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival. Another rom-com, _Playing It Cool_ (2015) also failed to make much of a mark, but _The Gifted_ (2017) fared far better, with Evans playing the guardian of a mathematics prodigy.

_The Red Sea Diving Resort_ and _Knives Out_
--------------------------------------------

Evans next starred as an Israeli agent in _The Red Sea Diving Resort_ (2019), based on the real-life rescue and transport of Ethiopian Jews to Israel in 1981. Late that year, he again distanced himself from the wholesome superhero image by playing an obnoxious playboy in the murder-mystery _Knives Out_. He followed in 2020 with a return to the small screen in the Apple TV+ miniseries _Defending Jacob_, as the father of a teenager accused of murder.

Net Worth
---------

Evans checks in at a cool $110 million, [according to Celebrity Net Worth](https://www.celebritynetworth.com/richest-celebrities/actors/chris-evans-net-worth/). The bulk of his fortune has come from his Marvel Cinematic involvement, though it took a little while to get there, after reportedly receiving a relatively modest $300,000 for his first _Captain America_ movie.

Romantic Life and Girlfriends
-----------------------------

Evans was involved in an on-and-off relationship with actress Jenny Slate after they got to know one another on the set of _The Gifted_. The couple spent the 2017 holiday season together, though they reportedly split for good a few months later.

Earlier in his career, from 2001 to 2006, Evans was in a long-term relationship with [Jessica Biel](https://www.biography.com/actors/jessica-biel). He has also been linked to actresses Minka Kelly and Lily Collins.

Twitter
-------

Outside of his movies, Evans has drawn the most attention for his unapologetically liberal tweets. When [Donald Trump](https://www.biography.com/political-figures/donald-trump) was elected U.S. president in 2016, the actor called it an “embarrassing night” in which fellow Americans “let a bully set our course.” He’s also tangled with former KKK head David Duke online, and slammed conservative news host Laura Ingraham for mocking student leaders who sought to curb gun violence. But not all of his tweets are of the politically charged variety, as he frequently pays tribute to friends and professional colleagues, and posts photos of his beloved rescue boxer, Dodger.

Chris Evans’ Height and Workout
-------------------------------

At 6 feet tall but naturally slim, Evans displayed the results of long hours in the gym while progressing from the rangy jock of _Not Another Teen Movie_, to the beefier Human Torch of _Fantastic Four_, to the cartoonishly muscular Captain America.

Packing on the pounds was vital to the appearance of his laboratory-enhanced superhero, prompting a training regimen that included high-weight reps of squats, deadlifts and incline bench presses, as well as bodyweight exercises like dips and pull-ups. By the time of _The Winter Soldier_, he had incorporated gymnastics and plyometrics to his routine for more speed and agility, aiding his efforts in such scenes as when he beats up a group of men in a crowded elevator.

Broadway Debut
--------------

In March 2018, while awaiting the release of _Infinity War_, Evans made his Broadway debut in a revival of Kenneth Lonergan’s _Lobby Hero_. As part of a small cast, which included his former _Scott Pilgrim_ co-star Michael Cera, Evans showcased his easy charm while hinting at the turmoil beneath the confident exterior of his veteran cop, Bill. Although _Lobby Hero_ had a limited run, Evans’ well-reviewed performance suggested he would eventually make his way back to the stage.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Personal Life and Interests
---------------------------

Evans isn’t the only member of his family who’s made a name for himself: His younger brother Scott also became an actor, holding down a regular role on the soap opera _One Life to Live_ for two years, while an uncle, Mike Capuano, is a former mayor and longtime Massachusetts congressman.

The Hollywood star has been open about his battles with social anxiety, particularly when it comes to the publicity aspect of his profession. As he told _Rolling Stone_, “You’re in the SUV with your family, your people. And then you have to pull over in some weird parking lot and do the swap. There’s security and all these people. All of a sudden you’re out of your comfort zone. ... It’s the little things that can tip you over.”

Evans, who splits his time between Los Angeles and Boston, is a serious sports fan who retains loyalty to hometown teams. In 2014, he narrated the NFL Network’s _America’s Game_, which recounted the New England Patriots’ run to a thrilling Super Bowl championship earlier that year.

Quotes
------

*   _I used to have thoughts of wanting to climb to the top of something, or wanting to be somebody. But when you get the thing that you think you want and then you wake up and realize that you still have pockets of sadness, and that your struggle will reinvent itself, you stop chasing after those things and it’s liberating, because you realize that right here, right now, is exactly all I need._
*   _I’ve stopped thinking about my trajectory, or my oeuvre, or whatever pretentious word you want to use. I’m just following whatever I feel creatively hungry for._
*   _I wasn’t into comic books. I had to go and do my research once I signed on for all these things._

[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0262635/bio/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm)
Christopher Robert Evans is an American actor, film producer, and director. Evans began his acting career in typical fashion: performing in school productions and community theatre.
He was born in Boston, Massachusetts, the son of Lisa (Capuano), who worked at the Concord Youth Theatre, and G. Robert Evans III, a dentist. His uncle is former U.S. Representative
Mike Capuano (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4576629/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
. Chris's father is of half German and half Welsh/English/Scottish ancestry, while Chris's mother is of half Italian and half Irish descent. He has an older sister,
Carly Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2869049/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, and two younger siblings, a brother named
Scott Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3268924/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, who is also an actor, and a sister named
Shana Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4974640/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
. The family moved to suburban Sudbury when he was 11 years-old. Bitten by the acting bug in the first grade because his older sister, Carly, started performing, Evans followed suit and began appearing in school plays. While at Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School, his drama teacher cited his performance as "Leontes" in "The Winter's Tale" as exemplary of his skill. After more plays and regional theatre, he moved to New York and attended the
Lee Strasberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0833448/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
Theatre Institute.
On the advice of friends, he landed an internship at a casting office and befriended a couple of the agents he regularly communicated with - one of whom later took him on as a client. The screen - not the stage - then became his focus; Evans soon began auditioning for feature films and television series. Evans made one of his first appearances on
The Fugitive (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247097/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
(CBS, 2000-2001), a remake of the 1960s series and feature film starring
Harrison Ford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000148/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
. In the episode "Guilt", Evans played the son of a small-town sheriff who tries to exact revenge after Dr. Richard Kimble - incognito as a liquor store owner - refuses to sell him and his friends alcohol. After small roles in
Cherry Falls (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0175526/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
and
The Newcomers (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0221431/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
- two unknown low-budget features - Evans appeared in
Boston Public (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247081/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
(Fox, 2000-2004) as a murder suspect. He then appeared in his first major feature,
Not Another Teen Movie (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0277371/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, a spoof on teen comedies wherein he played a jock who makes a bet that he can turn an unpopular and unkempt girl (
Chyler Leigh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0500200/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
) into prom queen.
After filming a couple of television pilots he was confident would be successful -
Just Married (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0305711/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
and
Eastwick (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362585/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
- he appeared in another listless teen comedy,
The Perfect Score (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314498/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, playing an average, ho-hum student who takes part in a plot to steal the SAT test. Hijinks naturally ensue. Then, Evans broke through to the Big Time, grabbing the lead in the kidnapping thriller,
Cellular (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337921/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, a suspenseful B movie with a cheesy gimmick - a random wrong number on his cell phone forces him into a high-stakes race to save an unknown woman's life. Despite an unassuming performance from Evans and
Kim Basinger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000107/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
as the damsel in distress,
Cellular (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337921/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
failed to break any box office records or please a wide majority of critics. Evans then prepared himself for super stardom when he signed on to play Johnny Storm in
Fantastic Four (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120667/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, 20th Century Fox's long-awaited adaptation of the Marvel comic. Although the film was wildly uneven and disappointing, Evans nearly stole the show with his energetic, unfettered performance. In that year itself, Chris was noticed by critics and made it into magazine and Internet countdowns, scoring himself a third position of the hot body countdown from Gay.com and #18 on E! Television's 2006 101 Sexiest Celebrity Bodies.
The year 2007 also proved to be one successful year for Chris, as he had two movies released around the world that same year, starting with the second installment of the Marvel franchise Fantastic Four. Chris received positive reviews for his performance.
The Nanny Diaries (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0489237/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, where Evans played Harvard Hottie, showed his sensitive. The year 2008 saw Chris Evans' part of the movie
Street Kings (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421073/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
, playing the character Detective Paul Diskant. The movie is about police officers trying to cover up their wrongdoings and audiences got to see a serious side of Chris. In the same year, Chris also worked on the movie
The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0896031/?ref_=nm_ov_bio_lk)
.
